title.narrative: Enhancing Food security, llivelihoods recovery and nutrition status for children, returning refugees

description.narrative: This project will strengthen the capacity for food self-sufficiency for 1,500 (655) households (80% women headed households) as primary beneficiaries and 7,500 (3276) individuals (as secondary beneficiaries) returnee refugees, IDPs and vulnerable members of host community households in Owach and Nyiluak payams of Malakal County. It will help affected communities to re-integrate and re-establish their own food production capacity that was eroded due to years of conflict and displacement. This is premised on the fact that own food production is the main source of livelihood for most South Sudanese and have practised farming for generations. Agriculture is an important and strategic opportunity for livelihoods and food security for IDPs, refugees and host communities. Humanitarian assistance has never been enough to cover all food security needs. Food shortages contribute to increased malnutrition among an already-particularly vulnerable children. Lack of access to food, coupled with a lingering and unpredictable economy that includes a devalued currency and chronic high inflation puts goods, services, and food beyond the reach of most IDPs, refugees and host communities. Food self sufficiency provides a stable foundation for households to engage in other pursuits such as economic opportunities. The project will focus on supporting farmers to improve farming practices as a strategy for increasing availability of staple foods such as sorghum, maize, sesame, cow peas. Kitchen gardens will be encouraged at household level for the production of nutritious vegetables as part of efforts to combat malnutrition.
